snippet: In response to Freedom of Information Act lawsuits by The New York Times and the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the government has declassified a set of previously secret motions and rulings involving the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The...
lead_paragraph: In response to Freedom of Information Act lawsuits by The New York Times and the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the government has declassified a set of previously secret motions and rulings involving the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The documents relate to the spy court’s then-secret decision in 2002 to eliminate a rule that required the Federal Bureau of Investigation to remove names and irrelevant information about innocent Americans picked up as part of wiretapping under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act before sharing information with the National Security Agency and the Central Intelligence Agency — and, starting in 2012, the National Counterterrorism Center.

headline.main: Government Declassifies Surveillance Court Documents on “Raw Take” Sharing
